claim: The majority of a set of numbers cannot be larger than the average.

supporting.text: By definition, the average of a set of numbers is calculated by summing all numbers and dividing by the count, meaning no majority can exceed it.

attacks.text: By definition, the average of a set of numbers is calculated by summing all numbers and dividing by the count, meaning no majority can exceed it.
If a set contains extreme outliers (e.g., one very large number and many small ones), the average may be skewed higher than most values.
Outliers are statistically rare in well-behaved datasets, so the original argument holds for typical cases.
In a bimodal distribution with two distinct clusters, more than half the numbers could lie above the overall average.
Bimodal distributions are specialized cases; the claim implicitly refers to unimodal or normally distributed data.

supporting.text: If a majority of numbers were larger than the average, their sum would disproportionately increase the average beyond those values.

attacks.text: If a majority of numbers were larger than the average, their sum would disproportionately increase the average beyond those values.
This assumes all numbers are positive; negative numbers could allow a majority to be larger than the average.
Negative numbers are rare in practical datasets where 'majority > average' is discussed, preserving A2's generality.
Identical values (e.g., all numbers equal) make the majority equal to the average, violating strict inequality.
Identical-value cases are trivial exceptions and don't represent meaningful counterexamples to the claim's intent.

supporting.text: Mathematical properties of averages ensure that more than half the data points cannot lie strictly above the mean in any finite set.

attacks.text: Mathematical properties of averages ensure that more than half the data points cannot lie strictly above the mean in any finite set.

This assumes a symmetric or unimodal distribution; in highly skewed distributions, a majority can lie above the mean (e.g., income distributions where most earn below average due to extreme outliers).
Even in skewed distributions, 'mean' is not always the relevant average—median or mode may better represent central tendency, preserving the original claim's validity for those measures.
The original argument specifies 'strictly above the mean,' which excludes equality. Cases where many points equal the mean (e.g., uniform discrete distributions) don't violate it.

supporting.text: The arithmetic mean balances deviations; a majority above it would imply an impossible distribution skewed infinitely upward.

attacks.text: The arithmetic mean balances deviations; a majority above it would imply an impossible distribution skewed infinitely upward.
In a right-skewed distribution (e.g., income data), the majority can be below the mean, but this does not preclude cases where the majority is above a different type of average (e.g., median).
The claim specifies 'average' without restricting it to the arithmetic mean, leaving room for ambiguity when considering other averages like median or mode.
Even with ambiguous definitions, the arithmetic mean's balancing property mathematically prevents a strict majority from exceeding it in finite datasets.
